title: 109_hr450
content: The Act may be cited as the "National Science Education Incentive Act of 2005". The Congress emphasizes the importance of maintaining the US's position in science and technology to advance human understanding and improve lives. Economic growth in the US is significantly influenced by advancements in science and technology. The growth of the United States today is directly linked to research and development in science and technology. Fundamental research explores the universe and seeks answers to new questions, while applied research applies these answers to everyday problems, making our lives more meaningful and livable. The United States' economic growth relies heavily on its intellectual capital and innovativeness, with education playing a critical role in developing this resource. The country needs scientists, engineers, and technologically proficient workers to drive research and development in a science-based, high-technology workplace. Student performance on international math and science assessments reveals shortcomings in US K-12 education compared to other countries. New teaching methods are needed to meet the demands of a science-based, high-technology workplace and to ensure scientifically literate voters and consumers. Improved teaching methods and curricula, along with teacher training and parental support, are essential for enhancing math and science education. Science is a process of inquiry based on observations and data, leading to a logical understanding of the universe through concepts and theories. Students should learn science by actively engaging in experiments and focusing on concepts. To enhance science education, teachers play a crucial role in connecting students with the content. It is important to identify and recruit high-quality, well-trained teachers who are respected by their peers and offer a rewarding career with opportunities for advancement. Teachers must have incentives to remain in the classroom, improve their practice, and be knowledgeable in their content area, curriculum, research in teaching, and techniques to connect with students. SEC. 3. Refundable credit for portion of tuition paid for undergraduate education of certain teachers. Amend Internal Revenue Code to include new section for tuition assistance for teachers. The new section of the Internal Revenue Code allows eligible teachers to claim a tax credit of 10% of qualified undergraduate tuition paid, up to a maximum of $1,000 per year. Teachers in high-needs school districts may receive this credit for the first 5 years of teaching. The new section of the Internal Revenue Code allows eligible teachers to claim a tax credit of 10% of qualified undergraduate tuition paid, up to a maximum of $1,000 per year. For secondary schools receiving funds under part A of title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act, the credit is increased to $1,500. No credit is allowed after the 10th year. An eligible teacher is defined as any individual for a taxable year. For a taxable year, any individual who is a full-time teacher in grades kindergarten through 12th grade, teaching math, science, engineering, or technology courses in grades 9 through 12 or kindergarten through 8 is eligible for a tax credit. For a taxable year, full-time teachers in grades K-12 teaching math, science, engineering, or technology courses are eligible for a tax credit if they have a relevant degree and are highly qualified. School administrative functions are also considered teaching courses. Administrative functions related to teaching courses in schools focusing on such courses are treated as teaching courses. Qualified undergraduate tuition refers to higher education expenses for enrollment at an institution of higher education. The term 'institution of higher education' is defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. The Secretary will prescribe regulations to carry out the purposes of this section. Conforming amendments are made to certain sections of the United States Code and the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The definition of 'institution of higher education' in the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended by adding new items. The text discusses amendments related to tuition for undergraduate education of certain teachers and overpayments of tax. It also mentions credits for contributions benefiting STEM education at the elementary and secondary school level. The effective date for these amendments is specified. The text introduces a new section in the Internal Revenue Code regarding contributions benefiting STEM education at the elementary and secondary school level. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code allows for a STEM contributions credit equal to 100% of qualified STEM contributions made by the taxpayer, including STEM school contributions, STEM teacher externship expenses, and STEM teacher training expenses. The term 'STEM school contributions' includes STEM property and service contributions. STEM property contributions refer to deductible amounts for charitable donations of STEM inventory to eligible schools in the US. The curr_chunk discusses the conditions for property donations to educational institutions in the US, emphasizing that the property must be used for educational purposes, fit into the donee's education plan, and not be exchanged for money or other property. The curr_chunk discusses deductions for STEM inventory property donations and STEM service contributions in the US. The curr_chunk explains the tax deductions for STEM inventory property donations and STEM service contributions in the United States. The curr_chunk defines 'property' and 'STEM services' for school contributions in STEM education. The curr_chunk discusses the provision of education in STEM subjects for grades K-12, including teaching courses in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. It also defines the 'defense dependents' education system' and STEM teacher externship expenses. The curr_chunk defines STEM teacher externship expenses as amounts paid for a program involving eligible STEM teachers in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. The curr_chunk defines eligible STEM teachers as individuals teaching in grades K-12 at educational organizations in the US or on US military bases, who receive training to enhance their teaching skills in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. The term 'STEM teacher training expenses' refers to costs incurred by a taxpayer in the fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics for training programs for eligible STEM teachers. Eligible teachers are those teaching in grades K-12 in the US or on US military bases. The curr_chunk discusses the denial of double benefit for deductions allowed under a training program for STEM teachers. It also includes conforming amendments to the tax code. The curr_chunk adds a new paragraph regarding the STEM contributions credit under section 45J. It also includes an amendment to the table of sections for subpart D of the tax code. The curr_chunk introduces a new section on contributions benefiting STEM education at the elementary and secondary school level. It also specifies that the amendments apply to taxable years after the enactment date. Additionally, SEC. 5 emphasizes the preservation of local control in educational institutions, prohibiting federal interference in curriculum, instruction, and administration.
